message.body: Are u at work? Can you talk?
Hey I'm in bed now. Is everything okay?
Yea.. neen has an interview mon and freaking out. Wanted to ask you some questions
Can we tAlk tmrw?
Yea. I'm here now that's why but one quick question. Did you ever get asked if you write a book about yourself what would the title be?
Oh geez no haha that sounds tough
Oh I thought you did. But ok ill tty tom. Can you try and think of some questions you have been asked? Then let me know tom

I've been asked mostly about my projects cause they were technical positions. Talking about things you've done is easy. Some times they ask behavioral questions. You can look those up online. The examples are pretty accurate
Yeah sure ill think
But a good place to start is googling behavioral interview questions.
Most interviews begin with "tell me about yourself"
What type of job is This?
Yea he has been googling tons of questions. I think he'll be fine but he panics and freezes and this interview holds a lot of pressure. But ok he is googling the behavioral ones now
A nd its for grad school. Usp.
Will give him his degree and experience
Like exactly what he is looking for
Also an important thing they will ask is if he has any questions for them. And he should think of 1-2 things.
Okay yeah grad school app is different
But those still Might be useful. I'll think of more
Yea he is also working on questions like why physical therapy. Why usp. Name a defining moment in your life. Etc
He justs stresses over unfamiliarity. Going to a new place for the interview. Then not knowing what to expect
Okay I'll think of advice about those.
Lol ok thanks. Ttyt
No problem. Night
You doing anything today? Might walk to walmart or target after work. Grab a few things. Seeing if your available for company
I grt done work at 3-330
I won't be back from work until around 5:45 or 6.
Oh that sucks. Ok nvm
Sorry

One thing I wanted to say for you to tell Steven. When I was an undergrad, I went to a session that talked about how to prepare for grad school. It was something started by the linguistics club, and a few Ling professors who were in charge of admissions into the masters/phd spoke there. They said for applications and interviews, when professor say "why X" like "why Linguistics", they don't want to hear things like "I loved it ever since I was a kid/I feel like it's my calling"
I don't know how true this is for every program but they made a big deal about it
Ok thanks

Yeah I think they look for answers like what specifically you like about the field and how you plan on using it to make a difference. I guess that's the difference between undergrad and grad. In grad school you have more of a direction and the school wants to see that you know what direction you're going
Ok ill tell him that too
